data: Partially reopened following extensive restoration work. Comprehensive collection of archaeological material, predominantly from the West of the island, with an important Etruscan collection.
Centre of Palermo, Piazza Olivella 24, 90100 - Palermo

Epitaph for Domitius Himeraeus, his sister Domitia and his wife Alfia Zotica
Three lines of roughly equal and centred latin letters filling the face of the stone, words separated by lightly carved interpuncts.
Bivona suggests that the onomastics (presence of tribal, use of Aulus and lack of cognomen in the sister's name) imply a date in the first half of the C1 CE

Bilingual sign advertising engraving of inscriptions

The text fills the face of the plaque, divided vertically by a deeply incised line into two unequal halves, with a column of Greek on the left (wider) and Latin on the right). Each column is approximately centred, and consists of seven lines of text, with the first two lines notably larger than the following five.

Augustan or Julio-Claudian,
                                by the letter forms; also, archaic spelling of some of the Latin, with other Sicilian
                                parallels, rules out much later date (so Wilson 1990); Manni Piraino thinks later 2nd century CE

The municipium of the Haluntini honours Gnaeus Pollienus
The text occupies five lines over the upper part of the front face.

The use of the term 'municipium' in Greek places this text almost certainly after the grant of Latin rights to Sicily by Julius Caesar (probably 46 BCE), but equally the use of Greek implies a date not later than the early Augustan period. The lettering is compatible with a late Hellenistic date.

Fragment of a monumental Greek inscription
Remains of three lines of large regular letters

Manni Piraino dates to the 2nd century CE simply on the basis of the theta, which seems implausible (and the site was not significantly active at this date). Given the monumentality of the lettering and the quality of the stone, dating so precisely by letter forms seems implausible, and a late Hellenistic date seems much more likely.
Photo from I.G.Palermo, pl.44.3, courtesy Palermo Museum

Entella 8 = A2, decree of Entella recording good will and isopoliteia with the people of Enna

Lines 1-5 fill the tympanon. Line 6 is engraved on the dividing strip, set to the left, avoiding the rivets. Lines 7-22 occupy the main body of the tablet and are left justified (but not right). The blank area at the foot of the tablet is equivalent to 3-4 lines of text.
First Punic War (264-241 BCE) and commonly attributed to the second half of the war.
